datas.title: Natural Numbers
paragraphs: Natural numbers are denoted by 'N'.numbers starting from '1 ' (one).

datas.title: Whole Numbers
paragraphs: Whole numbers are denoted by 'W'.numbers starting from '0' (zero).

datas.title: Even Numbers
paragraphs: Numbers which are the multiples of '2' are called 'Even Numbers '.

datas.title: Odd Numbers
paragraphs: Numbers which are not the multiples of '2' are called 'Odd Numbers'.
The smallest Natural Number is '1 ' and the smallest Whole Number is '0'.
There do not exist the largest Natural number and the largest Whole number.
The successor of any whole number is one more than that whole number.
Ex : Successor of 11 is 12, $@(11 + 1)@$
The predecessor of any whole number is one less than that whole number.
Ex : Predecessor of 11 is 10  $@(11 - 1)@$
There is no predecessor of zero in whole numbers.

p1: Face value of a digit is the digit itsell
Ex.: Face value of '5' in 325 is '5'
p2: Place value of a digit is the value of the digit in its place.
Ex. : Place value of '5' in 352 is 50 $@[5 \times 10]@$

datas.title: Consecutive Numbers
paragraphs: The Numbers which differ from each other by one are called 'Consecutive Numbers'.
Ex. : 13, 14 and 19, 20 are consecutive numbers

datas.title: Closure Property
paragraphs: Let a, b and c be any three Whole Numbers. Then

datas.title: Integers
paragraphs: Integers are the collection of all the Natural numbers with both positive and negative sign along with zero.

p4: Zero is neither positive nor negative.

datas.title: Absolute Value
paragraphs: The absolute value ofan integer is the numerical value (magnitude) irrespective of its sign.
$@Ex: \lvert 6 \rvert=6, and,\lvert -6 \rvert=6@$

datas.title: Closure Property
paragraphs: If 'a' and 'b' are any two integers then a + b is also an integer.

p1: '0' is the identity element in addition.
p2: '1' is the identity element in multiplication

p1: The additive inverse of any integer 'a' is '-a'.
Ex: The additive inverse of 4 is -4
p2: The multiplicative inverse of any integer 'a' is $@\frac{1}{a} (a \neq 0)@$
Ex : The multiplicative inverse of 4 is $@\frac{1}{4}@$

datas.title: Number line

p1: Every positive integer is greater than every negative integer.
p2: Zero is less than every positive integer.
p3: Zero is greater than every negative integer.

paragraphs: Every whole number on the right of the number line is greater than every whole number to its left.
geogebra:A(0,1);B(1,1);f(x)=Line(A,B);SetColor(f,'#32CD32');ShowLabel(f,true);ShowLabel(A,true);ShowLabel(B,true)

datas.title: Rational Number
paragraphs: A number which can be expressed in the form $@\frac{p}{q}@$ where 'p' and 'q' are integers and $@,(q \neq 0)@$ is called a Rational number.

datas.title: Reciprocal
paragraphs: Reciprocal of a rational number $@\frac{p}{q}@$ is $@\frac{q}{p}@$
Ex: Reciprocals of $@\frac{3}{5} is -\frac{5}{3}, -\frac{5}{7} is \frac{7}{-5}@$
The product of a rational number and its reciprocal is '1'.
If 'x' and 'y' are any two rational numbers, then $@\frac{x + y}{2}@$ is a rational number between 'x' and 'y'.
Ex : Let $@\frac{3}{2} and \frac{4}{3}@$ and be any two rational numbers, then $@\frac{ \frac{3}{2} + \frac{4}{3} }{2}  = \frac{17}{12}@$ is a rational number between $@\frac{3}{2} and \frac{4}{3}@$

datas.title: Decimal Representation of Rational Numbers
paragraphs: Every rational number can be expressed as a decimal.
Terminating and non-terminating decimals.

p1: Numbers with a finite decimal part are known as finite or terminating decimals.
p2: Numbers with infinite decimal part are known as non-terminating decimals.
Ex : $@\frac{1}{3} = 0.3333...@$ This can be expressed as $@= 0.\bar3@$

paragraphs: Representation of numbers in scientific notation.78
